name: Inguinal Canal Anatomy
theory:
Boundaries (MALT)

  • Muscle (Roof): Internal Oblique & Transversus Abdominis fibers (forming Conjoint tendon medially).
  • Aponeurosis (Anterior): External Oblique Aponeurosis.
  • Ligament (Floor): Inguinal Ligament (Poupart's) & Lacunar Ligament (Gimbernat's) medially.
  • Transversalis (Posterior): Transversalis Fascia.

Contents

  • Males: Spermatic Cord (Vas, Testicular Artery, Pampiniform plexus, Genital branch of Genitofemoral nerve) + Ilioinguinal Nerve (runs on top of cord).
  • Females: Round Ligament of Uterus + Ilioinguinal Nerve.
clinical:
Hernia Relevance

Deep Ring: Defect in Transversalis fascia. Located at mid-inguinal point. Site of Indirect hernias.
Superficial Ring: Defect in Ext. Oblique Aponeurosis.
Hesselbach's Triangle: Site of Direct hernias. Medial to Inf. Epigastric vessels.
Nerve Injury: Ilioinguinal nerve entrapment causes chronic groin pain/numbness in inner thigh/scrotum.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Mid-Inguinal Point vs Midpoint of Inguinal Ligament
Mid-Inguinal Point: Halfway between ASIS and Pubic Symphysis. Landmark for Femoral Artery and Deep Ring.
Midpoint of Inguinal Ligament: Halfway between ASIS and Pubic Tubercle. Landmark for Femoral Nerve block.

name: Calot's Triangle (Hepatobiliary)
theory:
Boundaries

  • Superior: Inferior border of the Liver.
  • Medial: Common Hepatic Duct.
  • Lateral: Cystic Duct.

Contents

  • Cystic Artery: Typically arises from Right Hepatic Artery.
  • Lund's Node: Sentinel lymph node of the gallbladder (enlarged in cholecystitis).
clinical:
Critical View of Safety

In Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy, Calot's triangle must be dissected to clear fat and fibrous tissue. Only two structures should be seen entering the gallbladder (Cystic Duct and Cystic Artery) before clipping. This prevents injury to the Common Bile Duct (CBD).
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Moynihan's Hump
A "caterpillar" tortuosity of the Right Hepatic Artery that loops into Calot's triangle. It can be mistaken for the cystic artery and accidentally ligated, causing right lobe liver necrosis.

name: Arterial Supply of the Gut
theory:
The Three Trunks (Aorta Branches)

  • Celiac Trunk (Foregut - T12): Stomach, Liver, Spleen, Pancreas, Proximal Duodenum.
    Branches: Left Gastric, Splenic, Common Hepatic.
  • SMA (Midgut - L1): Distal Duodenum to distal 2/3 Transverse Colon.
    Branches: Ileocolic, Right Colic, Middle Colic.
  • IMA (Hindgut - L3): Distal 1/3 Transverse Colon to Rectum.
    Branches: Left Colic, Sigmoidal, Superior Rectal.
clinical:
Watershed Areas (Ischemia Risk)

These areas have the poorest collateral blood supply and are prone to Ischemic Colitis (hypoperfusion).
Griffiths' Point: Splenic flexure (Junction of SMA & IMA).
Sudeck's Point: Rectosigmoid junction (Junction of IMA & Hypogastric/Iliac supply).
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Marginal Artery of Drummond
A continuous arterial arcade running along the mesenteric border of the colon, connecting the SMA (Middle Colic) and IMA (Left Colic) systems. Crucial for collateral flow in occlusion.

name: Femoral Triangle
theory:
Boundaries (SAIL)

  • Sartorius (Lateral).
  • Adductor Longus (Medial).
  • Inguinal Ligament (Superior).
  • Floor: Pectineus, Iliopsoas, Adductor Longus.
  • Roof: Fascia Lata.

Contents (Lateral to Medial: NAVEL)

  • Nerve (Femoral) - Outside the sheath!
  • Artery (Femoral).
  • Vein (Femoral).
  • Empty Space (Femoral Canal - Hernia site).
  • Lymphatics (Cloquet's Node).
clinical:
Femoral Hernia

Occurs through the Femoral Canal (Empty space).
Neck Boundaries:
- Anterior: Inguinal Ligament.
- Posterior: Pectineal Ligament.
- Lateral: Femoral Vein.
- Medial: Lacunar Ligament (sharp/rigid -> causes strangulation).
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Femoral Sheath
Contains the Artery, Vein, and Canal. The Femoral Nerve is NOT in the sheath (important for nerve blocks - must inject outside the vessels).

name: Breast & Axilla
theory:
Blood Supply

  • Arterial: Internal Mammary (Internal Thoracic), Lateral Thoracic, Thoracoacromial, Intercostals.
  • Venous: Matches arteries. Batson's Plexus (vertebral) allows metastasis to spine.

Lymphatic Drainage

75% to Axillary Nodes. 25% to Internal Mammary (Parasternal).
Axillary Levels (Berg's): Defined by Pectoralis Minor muscle.
- Level I: Lateral to Pec Minor.
- Level II: Behind Pec Minor.
- Level III: Medial to Pec Minor (Apical).
clinical:
Nerves at Risk (Mastectomy/Clearance)

  • Long Thoracic Nerve: Supplies Serratus Anterior. Injury -> Winged Scapula.
  • Thoracodorsal Nerve: Supplies Latissimus Dorsi. Injury -> Weak shoulder adduction/extension (

).
  • Intercostobrachial Nerve: Sensory to medial arm. Injury -> Numbness.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Sentinel Node
The first node draining the tumor. If negative, axillary clearance (and its morbidity/lymphedema) can be avoided. Identified using Blue Dye + Radioisotope.

name: Neck Triangles & Thyroid
theory:
Anterior Triangle

Borders: Midline, SCM, Mandible. Contains: Carotid sheath, Thyroid, Larynx.

Posterior Triangle

Borders: SCM, Trapezius, Clavicle. Contains: Spinal Accessory Nerve, Brachial Plexus, Lymph nodes (Level V).

Thyroid Relations

  • Strap Muscles: Anterior (Sternohyoid, Sternothyroid).
  • Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve: Runs in tracheoesophageal groove. Supplies all intrinsic larynx muscles (except Cricothyroid).
  • Parathyroids: Usually 4. Behind thyroid lobes.
clinical:
Nerve Injury Signs

Unilateral RLN: Hoarseness (vocal cord paramedic position).
Bilateral RLN: Airway obstruction (cords closed).
External Laryngeal Nerve: Loss of high pitch voice (Cricothyroid palsy) - "Singer's nerve".
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Fascial Layers
The thyroid is enclosed in Pretracheal Fascia, which attaches to the larynx/trachea. This is why the thyroid moves up on swallowing.

name: Abdominal Wall (Rectus Sheath)
theory:
Formation

Formed by aponeuroses of External Oblique, Internal Oblique, and Transversus Abdominis.

Arcuate Line

Located halfway between umbilicus and pubis.
Above Arcuate Line: Rectus abdominis enclosed front and back. (Ant: EO + 1/2 IO. Post: 1/2 IO + TA).
Below Arcuate Line: All aponeuroses pass Anteriorly. Posterior aspect is only Transversalis Fascia (weakness).
clinical:
Spigelian Hernia

Lateral ventral hernia occurring at the Linea Semilunaris (lateral border of rectus sheath), usually just below the Arcuate Line (area of weakness).
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Nerve Supply
Thoracoabdominal nerves (T7-T12) run in the plane between Internal Oblique and Transversus Abdominis (TAP plane). TAP blocks are used for analgesia.

name: Anal Canal
theory:
The Dentate (Pectinate) Line

Divides the canal into upper (visceral) and lower (somatic) halves.
Above Line: Endoderm. Columnar epithelium. Superior Rectal Artery. Portal venous drainage. Visceral sensation (stretch only - painless hemorrhoids). Adenocarcinoma.
Below Line: Ectoderm. Squamous epithelium. Inferior Rectal Artery. Systemic venous drainage. Somatic sensation (Painful hemorrhoids/fissures). SCC.
clinical:
Hemorrhoids

Internal: Above dentate line. 3 Cushions (3, 7, 11 o'clock). Bleed but painless.
External: Below dentate line. Painful if thrombosed.

Fistula-in-Ano

Goodsall's Rule describes the track path relative to the anal verge.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Portal-Systemic Anastomosis
The anal canal is a site of portosystemic anastomosis (Superior Rectal v. <-> Inferior Rectal v.). Portal hypertension can cause anorectal varices (distinct from hemorrhoids).

name: Classification of Hematuria
theory:
Definitions

  • Microscopic Hematuria: >3 RBCs per high power field. Not visible to naked eye. Detected by dipstick (highly sensitive) and confirmed by microscopy.
  • Macroscopic (Gross) Hematuria: Visible blood in urine. 1ml of blood can stain 1L of urine. Always significant.

Timing of Stream (The 3 Glass Test)

  • Initial: Bleeding from the urethra (trauma/inflammation).
  • Terminal: Bleeding from the bladder base/prostate (occurs at end of voiding as muscles contract).
  • Total: Bleeding from the kidney, ureter, or massive bladder bleed (blood mixed throughout).
clinical:
Diagnostic Approach

Painless Hematuria: Considered Urological Cancer (Bladder/RCC) until proven otherwise.
Painful Hematuria: Suggests Calculi (colic) or Infection (UTI/Cystitis).
Clots: Worm-like clots suggest ureteric molding (upper tract bleeding). Amorphous clots suggest bladder origin.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Red Flags
Painless gross hematuria in a patient >40 years old is a classic presentation of Bladder Cancer (TCC) or Renal Cell Carcinoma.

name: Routine Imaging Studies
theory:
Modalities

  • X-Ray (Plain Film): Uses ionizing radiation. Good for bones, free air (erect CXR), and bowel gas patterns (AXR). Poor soft tissue definition.
  • Ultrasound (USG): High-frequency sound waves. No radiation. Best for biliary tree, renal tract, scrotum, and blood flow (Doppler). Operator dependent.
  • CT Scan: X-rays in 3D slices. High radiation dose. Gold standard for acute abdomen, trauma, staging cancer. Contrast enhances vessels/organs.
  • MRI: Magnetic fields. No radiation. Superior soft tissue contrast (brain, spine, pelvis, biliary tree-MRCP). Slow and contraindicated in metal implants.
  • PET-CT: Functional imaging using FDG (glucose analogue). Detects metabolic activity (metastases/tumors).
clinical:
Contrast Media

IV Contrast (Iodine): Used in CT. Risk of Contrast-Induced Nephropathy (check eGFR) and Anaphylaxis.
Oral Contrast: Differentiates bowel loops from abscess/fluid collections.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Radiation Doses
1 Chest X-ray = 0.1 mSv (3 days background radiation).
1 CT Abdomen = ~10 mSv (3 years background radiation). Avoid CT in pregnancy/children if possible.

name: Routine Biochemical Tests
theory:
Panel Explanations

  • FBC (Full Blood Count):
    - Hb: Anemia (blood loss/chronic disease).
    - WBC: Infection (Neutrophilia), Inflammation.
    - Platelets: Clotting capacity (Low in sepsis/DIC).
  • U&E (Urea & Electrolytes):
    - Creatinine: Muscle breakdown product, specific for renal function.
    - Urea: Affected by hydration, GI bleed (protein meal), and catabolism.
    - K+: Critical electrolyte. Hyperkalemia causes cardiac arrest.
  • LFTs (Liver Function Tests):
    - ALT/AST: Hepatocellular damage (leak from cells).
    - ALP/GGT: Biliary obstruction (Cholestasis).
    - Albumin/INR: True tests of synthetic liver function.
  • CRP (C-Reactive Protein): Acute phase reactant. Lags behind clinical picture by 12-24h.
clinical:
Interpretation

Pre-renal Failure: High Urea, Normal/Mild Creatinine (Dehydration/GI Bleed).
Obstructive Jaundice: High ALP/GGT, High Bilirubin, Normal/Mild ALT.
Pancreatitis: Amylase >3x upper limit (diagnostic) but short half-life. Lipase is more specific.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Isolated Urea Rise
Elevated urea with normal creatinine is a classic sign of Upper GI Bleeding (digested blood is a protein meal absorbed from gut) or severe dehydration.

name: Shock
theory:
Definition

Acute circulatory failure leading to inadequate tissue perfusion and cellular hypoxia. It is defined by perfusion, not just blood pressure.

Classification

  • Hypovolemic: Loss of volume (Hemorrhage, Burns, Dehydration). Preload â†“.
  • Cardiogenic: Pump failure (MI, Arrhythmia). Contractility â†“.
  • Obstructive: Physical block (Tamponade, PE, Tension Pneumothorax).
  • Distributive: Vasodilation (Sepsis, Anaphylaxis, Neurogenic). SVR â†“.
clinical:
Management Principles

1. Recognition: Tachycardia is the first sign. Hypotension is a late sign (Class III hemorrhage).
2. Resuscitation: ABCDE approach. 2 Large bore IVs. Fluid challenge (Crystalloid). Blood products for hemorrhagic shock (1:1:1 ratio).
3. Vasopressors: Noradrenaline (for septic shock after fluids).
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Classes of Hemorrhage (ATLS)
I (<15%): Normal vitals.
II (15-30%): Tachycardia, Narrow Pulse Pressure.
III (30-40%): Hypotension, Confusion (Requires Blood).
IV (>40%): Lethargic, Anuric (Immediate threat).

name: Major Surgical Classifications
theory:
Risk Prediction

  • ASA Grade: I (Healthy) to V (Moribund). Predicts peri-operative mortality.
  • Child-Pugh: Grades Liver Cirrhosis (A-C). Uses Bilirubin, Albumin, INR, Ascites, Encephalopathy.

Wound Classification

  • Clean: No viscus opened (Hernia repair). Infxn risk <2%.
  • Clean-Contaminated: Viscus opened under control (Elective Chole/Colon). Infxn risk <10%.
  • Contaminated: Spillage/Inflammation (Acute Appendicitis). Infxn risk 20%.
  • Dirty: Pus/Perforation (Abscess/Perf Diverticulitis). Infxn risk 40%.
clinical:
Severity Scores

Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS): E4, V5, M6. Assessment of consciousness.
SIRS Criteria: Temp >38/<36, HR >90, RR >20, WBC >12/<4.
qSOFA: Hypotension, Altered mental status, Tachypnea (Quick sepsis screen).
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž WHO Safety Checklist
Mandatory 3-stage check: Sign In (Before anesthesia), Time Out (Before incision), Sign Out (Before leaving room). Reduces mortality by ~30%.

name: Preparation & Post-Op Care
theory:
Pre-Operative

  • Consent: Must be Voluntary, Informed, and with Capacity.
  • NPO (Fasting): 2h Fluids, 6h Solids (reduces aspiration risk).
  • VTE Prophylaxis: LMWH (Clexane) + TED stockings.
  • Antibiotics: Prophylactic dose given at induction (within 60 mins of incision) for clean-contaminated cases.

Post-Operative (ERAS)

Enhanced Recovery After Surgery: Multimodal pathway to reduce stress response. Includes: Minimally invasive surgery, Early mobilization, Early feeding, Opioid sparing analgesia, Avoidance of drains/tubes.
clinical:
Post-Op Complications (Day 0-7)

Immediate: Hemorrhage (Reactionary/Secondary), Hypothermia.
Early: Fever (5 W's), DVT/PE, Ileus, Acute Urinary Retention.
Late: Wound Infection (SSI), Anastomotic Leak (typically Day 5-7), Hernia.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Reactionary vs Secondary Hemorrhage
Reactionary: <24h. Slippage of ligature or dislodgement of clot due to rising BP.
Secondary: 7-10 days. Due to infection eroding a vessel.

name: Chemotherapy Principles
theory:
Settings

  • Neoadjuvant: Given before surgery to downstage tumor (shrink it) and treat micrometastases (e.g., Esophageal/Rectal Ca).
  • Adjuvant: Given after surgery to kill remaining microscopic disease and prevent recurrence (e.g., Breast/Colon Ca).
  • Palliative: Symptom control and life extension in metastatic disease.
clinical:
Common Regimens

5-FU (Fluorouracil): Backbone of GI cancer treatment.
Platinum agents (Cisplatin/Oxaliplatin): DNA cross-linkers.
Taxanes (Docetaxel): Breast/Prostate.

Side Effects

Neutropenic Sepsis (Emergency - give IV Abx immediately), Nausea/Vomiting, Alopecia, Neuropathy, Mucositis.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Neutropenic Sepsis
Defined as Temp >38Â°C with Neutrophils <0.5. Treatment is immediate broad-spectrum IV antibiotics (e.g., Tazocin) without waiting for blood results. High mortality.

name: Endoscopy Explained
theory:
Types

  • OGDS (Gastroscopy): Visualize Esophagus, Stomach, Duodenum (to D2). Diagnostic (Ulcers, Cancer) & Therapeutic (Variceal banding, Ulcer clipping).
  • Colonoscopy: Visualize entire colon + terminal ileum. Gold standard for CRC screening and polypectomy.
  • ERCP: Side-viewing scope to cannulate Ampulla of Vater. Visualizes biliary/pancreatic ducts. Therapeutic mainly (Stone removal/Stenting).
  • Flexible Sigmoidoscopy: Visualizes only rectum and sigmoid. Less sedation needed.
clinical:
Complications

Perforation: Rare (1:1000 diagnostic, higher therapeutic). Presents with surgical emphysema, pain, tachycardia.
Bleeding: Post-polypectomy.
Sedation risk: Respiratory depression (Midazolam/Fentanyl).
Post-ERCP Pancreatitis: 5-10% risk due to duct irritation.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž ERCP vs MRCP
MRCP: MRI-based, non-invasive, purely diagnostic.
ERCP: Invasive, therapeutic, risk of pancreatitis. Use MRCP to diagnose, ERCP to treat.

name: Wound Healing
theory:
Phases

  • 1. Hemostasis (Mins): Vasoconstriction, Platelet plug, Fibrin clot.
  • 2. Inflammation (Days 1-4): Neutrophils and Macrophages clean debris. Signs: Redness, heat, swelling.
  • 3. Proliferation (Days 4-21): Fibroblasts lay down Collagen III. Angiogenesis. Granulation tissue forms.
  • 4. Remodeling (3 weeks - 1 year): Collagen III replaced by stronger Collagen I. Scar matures and contracts.
clinical:
Types of Union

Primary Intention: Clean wound edges approximated by sutures. Minimal scarring.
Secondary Intention: Wound left open to heal by granulation (e.g., abscess/dirty wound). Slow, larger scar.
Tertiary Intention: Delayed primary closure. Left open initially for infection to clear, then sutured later.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž Factors Affecting Healing
Systemic: Age, Diabetes, Malnutrition (Vit C/Zinc/Protein), Steroids, Smoking (Hypoxia).
Local: Infection, Ischemia, Foreign body, Tension.

name: Surgical Nutrition
theory:
Importance

Malnutrition leads to wound dehiscence, infection, and muscle wasting.

Modes of Feeding

  • Enteral (Gut): Preferred. Preserves gut mucosal barrier, prevents bacterial translocation. Methods: Oral, NG Tube, NJ Tube, PEG.
  • Parenteral (IV): TPN (Total Parenteral Nutrition). Used when gut cannot be used (e.g., prolonged ileus, high output fistula, short bowel). Administered via Central Line due to high osmolarity.
clinical:
Refeeding Syndrome

Metabolic disturbance when feeding starved patients. Insulin surge drives K+, Mg2+, and PO4- into cells.
Risk: Severe Hypophosphatemia (Respiratory failure/Cardiac arrest).
Management: Start slow, supplement Thiamine and electrolytes aggressively.
pearls:
ðŸ’Ž TPN Complications
Catheter-related: Sepsis (fungal/bacterial), Pneumothorax during insertion.
Metabolic: Hyperglycemia, Liver dysfunction (fatty liver), Electrolyte imbalance.
